column10: How satisfied are you with your experience as a Lead Coach with the NYC Teaching Fellows?
column11: My Teaching Academy is a high quality place for PSTs to complete their Field Experience
column12: The administration at my Training Academy has a positive attitude towards NYCTF
column13: Please share any feedback about the culture at your Teaching Academy.
column14: I understand how my PSTs' performance was being evaluated.
column15: I understood the role I play in measuring my PSTs’ performance.
column17: The training prepared me effectively to support Coaches.
column18: I am comfortable actively intervening in Coaching conversations or during co-observations when the opportunity presents itself
column19: Please provide any additional information you would like to share about supporting Coaches.
column20: I felt supported by my Site Manager.
column21: I received useful feedback from my Site Manager that improved my ability to effectively manage my Coaches.
column22: My Site Manager answered my questions in a timely manner.
column23: The meetings we have as a Lead Coach team were valuable.
column24: Deadlines and expectations were clearly communicated to me.
column25: Please provide any additional information you would like to share about your Site Manager, including how s/he may better support you.
column26: Based on your experience with PSTs so far, to what extent do you agree with this statement 'PSTs have the potential to be effective teachers in their first year of teaching.'
column31: Have you worked with NYCTF in the past?
column32: I am more satisfied with my role compared to previous pre-service trainings.
column33: PSTs will be more prepared to teach rigorous common core aligned content than they were over the summer
column34: Please share any additional feedback you have on Fellow professionalism and interventions.
column35: Please provide any feedback on your relationship with the Fellow Effectiveness Manager (who observed your PSTs)
column36: Communications with the Fellow Effectiveness Managers have gone smoothly
column37: The feedback our PSTs received from their Fellow Effectiveness Manager was aligned to the feedback they received from Coaches.
column38: The Round 3 Fellow Effectiveness Manager was efficient and communicative in scheduling the final observation.
column39: Are you interested in participating in the program next year?
column49: How would you rate the level of Fellows’ openness to the Common Core Standards when they entered training?  (This will help us assess whether we are accurately capturing these mindsets during the selection process).

column13: Teachers love their Fellows and students truly miss them now...
column19: It is difficult to balance my classroom duties, coaching, and lead coaching duties.
column25: Lizette is awesome !!! She always answers my emails and text immediately.
column35: Managers were extremely efficient and detailed in their observations.
column49: Strongly supportive of the Common Core standards

column13: Our coaches had an overall good experience and that translated to the PSTs. The culture struggled most when there was a disconnect between what the coaches and fellows were telling PSTs.
column19: Supporting coaches was great, when there was time. Between my busy schedule and the coaches busy schedule, it is hard to get in coaching conversations and observe.
column25: I was very happy with Lizette. I would say that there tends to be some email overload with last minute changes that gets difficult to keep up with. When there are so many, it is easy to miss something important.
column34: It wasn't clear when we are supposed to be reporting issues with fellows, so we had an instance where the fellow didn't get their formal intervention early enough.
column35: One of the FEMs was very abrupt delivering feedback and made a few of our fellows cry. She didn't give anything specifically positive when she even acknowledged that there were good points in the lesson. It was demoralizing for our fellows. The other two were great.
column49: Neutral – no opinions

column13: My school embraced the PST's. Many teachers opened their classrooms and shared their knowledge. Over all, the Pst's were accepted and treated with respect.
column19: As a first time Lead Coach, I anticipated having difficulty. I am glad to say that I did not encounter any issues that weren't easy to resolve and the CC's were always very receptive.
column25: Mu site manager was very supportive. If any issues raised, she was supportive and informative. Even if she did not have the answers immediately, she always followed up in a timely manner.
column34: I am glad to say that the Fellows that was under my supervision and guidance was very professional and there were no interventions needed.
column35: Again, I am glad to say that my overall experience with the FEMS was positive. The only thing I observed was a FEM taking notes of her observations on her phone while the Principal was also observing the PST. We have a very strong NO CELL PHONE use in our school and really work hard at enforcing this with the students. It was not a great message to send to the students.
column49: Supportive of the Common Core standards

column13: As a whole we feel unsupported by NYCTA and did not enjoy the experience.
column19: Training and materials geared toward Teaching Fellows not traditional route PSTs.
column25: Site manager unable to answer questions about EdTPA and knew more about Teaching Fellows (which we did not have) than traditional route PSTs.
column35: We did not have Teaching Fellows.
column49: Supportive of the Common Core standards
Supportive of the Common Core standards
Neutral – no opinions

column13: The culture at my school preaches routine, structure, and high expectations for student learning. These are concepts that I feel are essential for new teachers to develop.
column49: Supportive of the Common Core standards

column19: I feel like I will be better equipped and more confident in future semesters.
column35: There are very unique situations in Special Education and ESL at the high school level. It is difficult to have an observer in the classroom if they are not familiar with the set up or make up of the class and if they do not understand what an ICT classroom is at the high school level. It was also frustrating to have had to type up the schedules of the CCs and then not to have anyone look at it seemed like that time could have been better spent doing something else.
column49: Neutral – no opinions

column13: We have a very collaborative environment where teachers are constantly working in teams to reflect and refine their practice. Which is important for new teachers to see, that teaching is not an isolated activity and that it is best practice to share resources and tools with your colleagues. They need to be exposed to the different ways they can be supported as a new teacher whether it is formally through a mentor or informally during a department meeting or a team meeting.
column19: I think that since many coaches have different needs it was challenging at times to find the time to support them while having a full teaching load myself and also having to think about my own formal observations outside of the NYCTA.
column25: Odette was able to get all of my questions answered within 24-48 hrs and was very responsive to my emails. I think in the future it would be beneficial in terms of transparency and communication to create a running agenda or minutes on a google doc so we can refer to them every time she would visit the site. I also have to say that Odette always brought a warm energy every time she visited BWA and was also goal-oriented as she helped me problem solve through some issues.
column34: I would suggest having exemplars prepared of phrases to document onto TT2 (since many of us had some challenges using the online platform). I think in terms of managing expectations, reminding PSTs of expectations in regards to attendance, lateness and attire rather than the CCs relaying the information.
column35: I found that there wasn't necessary a consistency in terms of how I received the schedule/information from the FEM when they were arriving. 2 of the FEMs were able to give me access to their feedback and were willing to have a debrief conversation with me and the coach if they had any concerns. I think the other FEM was just overwhelmed with the number of schools they had to visit. She has issues scheduling all of the observations on one day and did not think she needed to accommodate the PSTs schedule. It was hard because we didn't have time to really engage with them but other than that all 3 were pleasant and communicated with me to some degree.
column49: Neutral – no opinions

column13: I found that in the beginning, a couple of the CC's that had fellows were not on board with the entire idea. It made for a difficult start. As the time progressed and it became more routine people were more excited about the fellows.
column19: Some of the coaches chosen were resistant toward the program making it difficult to approach them. I would like the administration to be more informed about expectations and help set the guidelines as I am a teacher just like them.
column25: This was the start of something new for some of the site managers, I found when I emailed Lizette I was immediately responded to. When I emailed my site manager, it would take some time to get answers as she was still learning. I feel with time, this will get better.
column34: I believe that fellows need to be better informed about expectations. I felt that many of the fellows thought they were doing us a service and we were here strictly to serve them. They complained about their commute and many things that most principals would not deal with. I feel like informing the PSTs that this is a program they decided to join and that they need to be more flexible and willing to do whatever they can do get through the program efficiently is essential.
column35: All of the FEMs in my personal experience were fine. I do strongly feel that district 75 needs to be given specific people that know and understand the population.
column49: Supportive of the Common Core standards

column13: It was a lot of work for all of the teachers. A lot of miscommunication amongst staff in teaching fellows and the teaching academy staff
column19: just more communication between the 2 programs.
column34: I was not overly impressed with the PSTs. They all had an issue at one point or another.
column35: they were ok. The second one observed and caused some issues and fights between the fellows.
column49: Neutral – no opinions

column13: Our CCs are really incorporating the PSTs into the classroom.
column19: Not having access to TT2 meant that I as the Lead Coach couldn't often give advice to my CCs when they were confused--they relied on each other to troubleshoot.
column25: Lizette was very supportive and very helpful.  I loved that she was super flexible based on the school's needs.  I felt respected and supported by her.  The only thing I would change is the out of school time training--it was a LOT of time including transport time, and I wasn't clear on that commitment before the program started.  Additionally, as a TIF teacher, I wasn't compensated for that time, which seemed unfair!
column49: Supportive of the Common Core standards
Supportive of the Common Core standards

column13: Our teaching academy is highly collaborative and communicative amongst themselves. PST's seem to feel comfortable and have absorbed and emulated the culture of our school.
column19: There didn't seem to be a definitive role for LC's in regards to CC's and PST's. Much of the LC role was paperwork and following up on deadlines. I don't understand how I was supposed to support coaches in coaching, especially as my site has high quality coaches who are all experienced. Much of the meeting time was spent learning how to navigate a growing system (NYCTA) instead of working on coaching skills.
column25: It would be helpful next time around if LC's received weekly action updates of the small pieces we need to manage on a daily / weekly basis. Reading a newsletter and modifying a session written by someone else every week isn't reasonable, especially considering that LC's are also full time teachers. Additionally, much of the "support" provided was not appropriate or applicable for my site or my coaches.
column35: FEM's were generally cordial and professional. However, they did not seem qualified to be evaluating good teaching. Using a rubric and grounding all evaluations ONLY in the language of the rubric without understanding the nuances of teaching and learning in an ineffective way to evaluate new teacher development.
column49: Neutral – no opinions

column19: Since TT2 was so confusing at the beginning it made it difficult to support my coaches in that area, but this was simply a computer issue. P
column34: I had some issues with professionalism. The office was quick to help us out which was great.
column49: Neutral – no opinions
Neutral – no opinions
Supportive of the Common Core standards
Mildly opposed to the Common Core standards, but open to changing their mind

column19: I feel comfortable due to my past experience with Nyctf.
column25: Angela was very supportive and available to answer questions.
column34: Interventions were not clearly communicated to fellows.
column35: They had zero D75 experience and did not understand d75 rigor, lesson alignment or how to appropriately manage behavior.
column49: Neutral – no opinions

column13: All the staff was very supportive and welcoming. Admin took the time to meet with fellows and ask for their feedback. Overall, a rewarding experience for everyone.
column35: I feel that some FEMs did not have sufficient teaching experience or any experience in D75, thus making it challenging for some coaches to align their knowledge of our students with theirs.
column49: Supportive of the Common Core standards
